Importing Work Records

With the StarTeam Microsoft Project Integration, you can import the number of hours worked and the number of hours remaining from StarTeam  work records. These work records can be associated with a single task, a task hierarchy (the selected task and its children), or all the tasks linked to the current Microsoft Project (.mpp) file.

When importing work records, be aware of the following:

  • If a user unknown to Microsoft Project has worked on a task in StarTeam, the application asks if the user should be added as a resource to that Microsoft Project task and the .mpp file.

  • If a user known to Microsoft Project has worked on a StarTeam task to which he or she is not assigned, the user is automatically added to the resources for the task in Microsoft Project.

A Microsoft Project task has one cumulative work record for each resource, while StarTeam may have several records for the same individual.

Important: Always import work for a StarTeam task into the .mpp file before selecting the Sync StarTeam Tasks command from the StarTeam menu in Microsoft Project. Otherwise, the work hours for the task in StarTeam will be negatively adjusted to equal the previous work entered but not imported into Microsoft Project. The comment for this adjustment in the StarTeam work record will read: "Adjusted for Microsoft Project plan change.” This adjustment occurs by design, because the Sync StarTeam Tasks command overwrites information in StarTeam.

To import work record information from StarTeam to Microsoft Project:

  1. Select a task in Microsoft Project for which you want to import the StarTeam work record.

  2. Select StarTeam > Import Work from the Microsoft Project menu. The Import Work Records dialog appears.

  3. Select one of the following import options:

    • Selected task only (disabled if no task selected).

    • Selected task and children (disabled if no task selected or if the selected task has no children).

    • All exported tasks (default).

  4. Click OK.

To see work imported in Microsoft Project:

  1. Select a task in Microsoft Project.

  2. Select Window > Split from the Microsoft Project menu. The window splits into two panes, with the upper pane showing your tasks and the lower pane shows data fields containing the name of the task, its duration and so on. Beneath these fields are one or more tables with column headers.

  3. To display a context menu, right-click a column header in a table.

  4. To see the resources for the task, select Resource Work from the context menu. The lower pane now displays only one table, which lists the resources for the task and other work-related information. The last two columns of the table are Act. Work (actual work) and Rem. Work (for remaining work). The data in these two columns comes from StarTeam.

  5. Update the Gantt charts. The procedure for doing this depends upon several factors, such as how work is measured and whether the project needs to be leveled.
